titleStmt.title: T.H. Lacy's Acting Edition of Victorian Plays (1848-1873) : a bibliography
titleStmt.author: Revised and extended by Lou Burnard

sourceDesc.p: This is an enhanced and extended version of the catalogue of Lacy's Acting Edition originally created by the now sadly defunct Victorian Plays Project, originally directed by Dr Richard Pearson at the University of Worcester.

That catalogue has been cross-checked against several other sources of information. Various minor errors and inconsistencies have been corrected, and additional information added, particularly about available digitizations of the plays.

list.label: Identifiers
list.item: Each entry in the catalogue has been given a unique identifier beginning with "L", followed by a four digit sequence number; these "Lacy numbers" correspond with the numbers used in the original published lists and individual text copies. In a few cases, Lacy appears to have replaced one or more titles in the printed volumes subsequent to their first appearance (see below for details); these replacement titles have been given an identifier suffixed with an R. The identifier used for the title in the original Victorian Plays Project is also cited, as is its identifier in my transcription of Allardyce Nicoll's Handlists.
list.label: Authorship
list.item: Authors' names have been standardised, in the form "Surname, Forenames-or-initials" following the most frequent usage in cases of doubt. Square brackets are used to indicate that the author name contained within them is not attested in this form on the title page of the work in question; sources for such attributions include Nicoll's Handlists, the Adelphi Theatre Catalog, manuscript annotation of the source, or presence of the title in a "By the Author Of" title elsewhere. Quotation marks are used to distinguish pseudonyms. In a few rare cases where no author is given and none has been plausibly identified, the author is given as "[Anon.]". In several cases, multiple author names are given. A personography of Lacy's Authors is under construction.
list.label: Title details
list.item: The entry for each title begins with a main title, rendered in italics. This is followed by one or more subtitles, indicating the type and length of the piece, or its source in the case of a translation or adaptation, as given on the title page.
list.label: Performances
list.item: For most entries, the date and location of the first performance is provided, as indicated either by the source or by the corresponding entry for this title in Nicoll's Handlists. Where this information is given by both sources, an earlier date is to be preferred; both datings are retained if they differ. Details of later performances are also supplied for some titles when these are present in the source.
list.label: Links
list.item: Clickable links to at least one online version are provided for almost all titles. These indicate the library holding the source (e.g. "LoB" for "Library of Birmingham", "UM" for "University of Michigan"), and the distribution agency (e.g. "HT" for "Hathi Trust", "VPP" for "Victorian Plays Project"). A list of other abbreviations used is given below.

[Taylor, Tom];[Coyne, Joseph Stirling]The Vicar of WakefieldAn Original Drama in three acts60 pp (UW copy)New Strand Theatre4 March 1850J. Stirling Coyne is listed as the author of a play of this title on the title-page of his play "My Wife's Daughter" also in this Volume. However, in Volume 1, the anonymous play, "The Philosopher's Stone" is attributed to the author of "The Vicar of Wakefield" and "Diogenes", whilst "Diogenes" (Volume 1) is attributed to the author of "Parents and Guardians". This latter is known to be by Tom Taylor, and Nicoll lists Taylor as the author also of "The Vicar of Wakefield". It is plausible that this play was co-authored by Taylor and Stirling Coyne, although they are not known to have collaborated on anything else. "Sir Roger de Coverley" (Taylor) (Volume 4) is also listed as being by the author of "Diogenes", "The Vicar of Wakefield", "The Philosopher's Stone", and "Prince Dorus".Vol02/L0020/L0020-vpp.pdf Vol02/L0020/pages Vol02/L0020/Vol02vVicar.pdf N18931Vol02vVicar

bibl.title: Up to Town and Back Again by The “Old York Highflyer”

Mr Rayner's Popular Entertainment, Comprising a Variety of Tales, Anecdotes, Recitations, Oddities, Whims, and Eccentric Pictures, from Nature; Particularly Killing Jenny -- The Riding System -- A Visiting Frenchman -- Stages of Loves from Twenty to Sixty -- Love and Ladyfoot -- The Smoking Age -- Amateur Whip -- Village Club -- Cross Readings -- Wonderful Alterations -- A Curious Law Trial to Recover a Whipping -- A Wine Party Degrees of Drunkenness -- Hope I Haven't Tired You, &c., &c. Including the Popular Songs of Guy Fawkes; We Shall Never See the Like Again, Cruel Courtship, The Gallimaufry, English, Irish, and Scotch Medley, Undeniables, The Chapter of Toping, London Oddities, to Which is Added the Monopolylogue of The Yorkshire Gamester, in Which is Introduced the Favourite Comic Song of The Loves of Humphrey Suckit and Betty Bouncer

div.head: Replacement titles
div.p: The selection of titles making up each volume seems to have changed very little during the course their long printing history. Certainly the lists of titles which appear occasionally in the printed volumes show little variation. However, a small number of titles do change between their first appearance -- if we are to believe the printed lists -- and their appearance in the 93-volume HathiTrust edition digitized by Google from a copy at the University of Michigan.The present catalogue includes both the original title, and its replacement, distinguished by the R suffix.For example, the sixth title in volume 1 has two versions, both given the number1.6. In the advertising pages consulted, this title is text L0006, Bayly'sLadder of Love. However, in the HT edition, the sixth title in volume 1 is Murray'sNo!, to which we therefore give the identifier L0006R. A list of these modifications follows. The dates given are those of the first performance according to the copy, where this is supplied.

div.p: The above table suggests that the replacement titles were almost always much older works, presumably available in house to replace any play which we may hypothesize Lacy had been cautioned against including since he had lost (or never held) the rights to it.
